beer_brewer_name: La Face Cache de la Pomme
review_blob: Bottle generously shared at a mcberko tasting. I really like this cider! It extends well beyond the apple and reaches transcendence in a form rarely realized in ciders that are not ice ciders. The pour is warm golden bronze, still as promised, and welcoming. I love its complex dryness, its crispness and brightness, all of which makes it supremely drinkable, moreish. It is never sweet but never tart either--the balancing act is lovely. Subtle mustiness yet never chalky, the yuzu/kumquat family of small, friendly citrus, carambola and other innocuous fruit throughout and imparting a holistic quality that transcends fruit in the way a superior white wine would do. There are many things to enjoy and it would be a welcome table cider if it were widely available.
beer_name: La Face Cache de la Pomme Inspiration 2013

review_blob: Draft at St. Augustine. Copper color thin head. Huge dried persimmon aroma. Soft silky palate, big bitterness and astringency fm huge persimmon, big tannins reminiscent of tea. Brett is just starting to kick in, but leaves its imprint by being bone dry. Is more bitter than sour. Would be curious to try this at different stages of its age and development. I totally understand this beer. It invokes the spirit of the persimmon, its not something you would want to drink regularly, just like you would not want to eat persimmon regularly.
beer_name: Elysian 12 Beers of Apocalypse #11 - Mortis: Sour Persimmon Ale

review_blob: Draft at the brewery. Gold and bright, love the choices of hop and malt with pale malt and dry bitter hop profile with no estery hop and not a chewy PACNW IPA, its actually pale and more British in character, yay! Another that the cans/bottles dont do it justice.
beer_name: Fernie Lone Wolf India Pale Ale

review_blob: Draft at brewery. One of the best Fernie beers. Solid malt character and nice lingering bitterness. Its very germanic and yum, nice to see in the lineup.

Draft at the brewery. Almost didnt try this one bc Im a raging snob but was much better than expected! Color of blush wine 3
Drier all round no overt fruit no soda, just the slightest whisper of fruit acidity blends well with the malts slight bitterness in the finish. Light body and thoroughly refreshing, no complaint really.

Draft at Boxwood. Looks nice. Stable big tight frothy head that wont stop, loads of poppin fresh pale malts in the aroma, no yeast overload, super soft palate, light, big coriander and orange flsvors up front leading to mellow malty middle. Sweet finish starts to cloy after a pint but still is a nice brew.

Draft at Saraveza. Beige and hazy. It smells nutty wheaty good and salty sweet. The lively thirst quenching body enlivens and nourishes. It is hydrating and perfect, everything i look for in a gose. The underlying sweetness balances the salty fresh malt nom nom. Damn this is an impressive brew I could drink a lot of.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
beer_name: Anderson Valley Highway 128 The Kimmie, The Yink, and the Holy Gose

review_blob: Draft at brewpub. Opaque black with small stable head. This one is clean. Lots of licorice notes, some cola, nice flavors in that pocket (low to no roast). Light carbo and smooth. Thin slightly syrupy. Actually quite good and the winner of the bunch.

Draft at brewpub. Hazy yellow, flat looking. Aroma has some problems; doughy, musty, and crumby. Awful actually muddled and weird. Syrupy palate but thin; I dont even know how to describe the problem...sawdust? Phenol? I find it undrinkable.

Draft at brewpub. Is bright gold, with small head and looks pretty good. Dry and resinous but not hoppy; clean and not yeasty. A bit austere, but actually not bad for what I suspected to be kit beer; if it were hoppier it would be like a Hoa Vien!

beer_brewer_name: The Heid Out / Fisher Peak Brewing
review_blob: Draft at brewpub. Amber with nice stable head. Aroma of random hop pellets. Thin. Dry and nicely bitter finish with piney hop, actually not bad and likely my favorite of the bunch.

beer_brewer_name: The Heid Out / Fisher Peak Brewing
review_blob: Draft at brewpub. Dark brown with thick head. Chocolatey aroma and mild cocoa dusting throughout. Drinkable but thin.

beer_brewer_name: The Heid Out / Fisher Peak Brewing
review_blob: Draft at brewpub. Thick stable head, aroma of bespoke house yeast, thin, cardboard, dry barley malt flakes, and white pepper...thin and soft body, dry is ok but sadly no body or even any sweetness from malt.
beer_name: Fisher Peak Soggy Otter Brown Ale

beer_brewer_name: The Heid Out / Fisher Peak Brewing
review_blob: Draft at brewpub. Clear amber, scant head/lace, caramel toasty caramel aroma, thin and sweet, but clean, with cookie and graham cracker malts.
beer_name: Fisher Peak Sams Beer Honey Lager

beer_brewer_name: The Heid Out / Fisher Peak Brewing
review_blob: Draft at brewpub. Hazy with thick pillowy head, spicy low ester aroma, soft palate, does not taste like a German hefeweiss yeast was used. Dry with a doughy sweetness finishing it off.

beer_brewer_name: The Heid Out / Fisher Peak Brewing
review_blob: Draft at brewpub. Rather clear for an unfiltered but nice lacing. Mineraly aroma, some sockiness, sweet body, not nearly enough hops for a pils but clean and nice effort.
beer_name: Fisher Peak Heid Out Helles Unfiltered Pilsner

review_blob: Draft at brewery. Is a dull sewery amber with a head that vanishes too soon, caramel and light cocoa in aroma, light soft carbo, sweet but finishes clean without offensive caramel flavors like a rickards might have. Not bad for what it is, all in all.

Rated at the brewery, draft. Pale straw yellow, stable splotchy head, its actually fine except for the sweetness, clean, and has a very soft mouthfeel. Aches for hops, and not sure how many Id drink, but I finished my pint and is not bad for what it is.

Draft at brewery. Dark dense compacted raspberry jam color with a small but lasting pink cap. Nose a bowl of raspberries and memories of Liefman's raspberry. Super refreshing bc of the lively carbonation. Some yeast in the finish; otherwise a pure berry mouthfeel with moderate tartness, not a lot of seed bitterness, and low sugars. Honest and balanced. Chewing on raspberries but not jammy. Seed bitterness would really kick this into the next level but it's still a really impressive brew and likely one of my personal Brassneck favourites.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Fiulijn, and a million thanks because this is the stuff that rocks my world. Appearance 4 hazy orange, actually quite a delightful looking pour with a small head at first, has quite a bit of carbonation and the cork had a really healthy sounding pop. Intoxicating aroma!!! Perfect 10. Blood orange peel, bright hoppy diamonds and stardust with a gin martini finish. Cant stop nosing it...body 4, light, soft effervescence alive, lively fruit and juice middle balancing and offsetting the astringency, which is an awesome feature with underripe starfruit, sucking dry the apricot kernels and cherry pits till the last tendrils of fruit meat are clinging to the stones and a satisfying bitterness ensues...Honestly I live for superlative amazing transcendental beer like this. Happiness in a bottle.

Draft at St. Augustines. Glad I chose to take a chance and sample this. What a surprise. The aroma is bright and fresh with mint and toast. The alternate malts are really amazing here, these brewers are expert craftsmen. I was convinced they had smoked something because I kept detecting peat smoke. There is a whole lot of flavor layered, with generous hopping that never seems out of balance. The body is quite substantial for a GF beer. If you think about it hard, the lack of malt sugars makes for a slightly thin body, but again, only if I think hard about it. Ive had way thinner bodies and thinner flavors from barley beer. It would be quite easy for me to pint this one. This is the GF that can fool you.

Draft from brewery. Amber with frothy loose white head. Intense bright kumquat-like, hard to peg but def dry...what really shines for me is the malt profile and the overall body. Superb malts, toasty but pale, sweet juicy middle and yet loads of lingering bitterness. Soft in the tongue. Delightful ISA gets better by the sip! Uprated :-)

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
beer_name: Powell Street Belma Flew into the Citra Galaxy

review_blob:
Bottle at MBerkos tasting. Opaque warm dark brown. This beauty reveals itself layer by layer, with the bourbon barrel vanilla late to the game subtle and welcome; no onslaught of hop; supremely balanced and so smooth; the herbal lift from the caraway. Best bw ive had in years.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
beer_name: Flossmoor Station Bourbon Barrel-Aged Hi-Fi Rye Wine

review_blob:
Bottle at Mberkos house. Blonde with slight pink haze. Gorgeously dry aromas and flavors unfold with citrus pith centerpoint. Not much peach character at all, with little residual sweetness--just enough for supreme balance and even a pinch of salt at the end. Live this brew, one of the best in show.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Legacy. Hazy, pretty much opaque soft orange color. The aroma is hop-forward, somewhat chewy and actually smells stronger than it is, but not in a bad way. The body is deceptive, it is fairly big, but highly drinkable. The best thing about this beer is its level of refinement. The fruit component is understated, adding nuance to a solid base beer rather than becoming an overly fruited gimmick. In fact, if I didnt know there was orange here, I would not detect it. Its more like, oh, thats where that balancing bit of acidity comes from. Solid malt profile, mainly pales, with briskly hopped. As with most Elysian beers, accessible and sophisticated at the same time.

Draft at Craft. Amber with a pretty nice lace and dry leafy hop aroma. The distinguishing feature is the wack of curry leaves all over the palate. At times, it tastes like a Pakistani grocery store. I like the medium to light body too. Pretty good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Gibsons LDB. As soon as it pours, I like it. The head, it is luscious thick and frothy. Lasts long. Oh, and purple. The aroma has dense fruit, blackberry and currant with boozy edge. Soft palate. Booze around the edges edges in a good way. The finish is bitter and dry. The distinguishing feature is a jamma wamma of fruit seeds. Not typical sour. Would not call it that, has a healthy malt backbone and no gimmick. Healthy malt healthy fruit. Fruit forward! Thats it, natural bitterness of berry seeds. Best of session.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Craft. 21k golden with a whisper of haze. Delicate lacy head and tendril lace. Dry aroma invokes bay leaf. Gentle carbonation, neither soft nor hard with some pleasing granularity. Lingering grassy bitterness echoes noble hops, and in my mind this is a hoppy pilsner! I dream of beer like this. I wish there was a law that all breweries have to brew a beer like this--one that is sublimely dry with no nonsense. This beer rocks!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Thick opaque black, with thin tan cap. Aroma is rather sharp, not in an alcoholic way, in a molasses and macaroon dough way. Oak chips are evident in the aroma, but the molasses overpowers everything. Intense, big, and sweet. No star anise at all, it is completely lost. The palate is thick and overwhelmed by molasses, so if you like molasses you are in luck. Would go great with dessert. If you do not like molasses you will hate it. Slightly burnt finish. Not a sophisticated beer, but it is enjoyable enough. Hell, if you dont like it, you can easily baste ribs with this stuff!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at the brewery. Lovely appearance, really. Warm, glowy mahogany, with a stable head. The aroma has a lot of booze, followed by cocoa butter. Evident heat signals strength. Solid body. The flavors are all about toffee and cocoa butter, and the alcohol goes to my head. I imagine 6.5 is a low estimate and this is actually stronger. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at brewery. Pink and hazy. The beer is thin, has little complexity, and no compelling features except for the pleasant astringency. Nothing right or wrong, with soft drink character.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at brewery. Black and brown head. I do not like this as much as I like the regular Inertia. The bourbon barrel imparts lovely wood and vanilla, and that is nice but strips the beer of its innate character. Boozy and happy, and those who love barrel will like this.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
beer_name: Brassneck Inertia II Bourbon Barrel Aged Imperial Stout

review_blob:
Draft at brewpub. Very dark brown with a light tan head. Easily distinguishable from Inertia bc of head color but otherwise similar. What malt is there? It's got a touch of chocolate malt but not a lot. It's got a muesli thing. Not toasty, not sweet. Not husky. Just right. Compelling and pure. Nourishing. Healthy. Dry. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at the brewpub. Murky brownish red. I must have put a quarter in the bubblegum machine, because gumball is all I think about. It manages to be drinkable in the 4oz size but after that, I might have left it over. These guys make superb beers (eg. the flagship pale and Inertia...) but not Belgian styles. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at brewery. Hazy unfiltered look with scattered lace. This really makes an impression on me. The outstanding feature is the freshness of the malt, which is reminiscent of German and even Franconian level brightness and peak of freshness. Like an ur-beer. Totally delicious, understated subtlety, and showcasing the talents of this brewhouse.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. The chestnut brown color suffers somewhat by being muddled. But it doesn't look bad, and it's got a decent head. The clean aroma esters are spot on with light banana, cola, and ginger in the aroma. There is no stickiness on the palate; this is a pleasant surprise and keeps it drinkable. The mouthfeel is fluffy and soft. Great flavor development. Dark cocoa character expresses itself especially well, finishing with pleasant bitter chocolate without ever being too sweet. Velvety smooth and balanced. It is hard to make this style of beer well. Impressive!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught at the brewery. Pitch black with nice chocolate brown head. Aroma is smooth dark chocolate, about 65%, and the palate is creamy, soft, and luscious. The flavors add a dimension of fresh roasted ground coffee beans. Dangerously drinkable!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This beer is lovely, thanks to Oakes for the find :) it has a lot of Turkish dried apricot character in all respects. The color, the juicy middle, the fructose finish, the balancing acidity. The lively hop and brett add extra dimensions, allowing both to sneak into tasty and proper pockets of happiness. The brett is apparent most in the aroma, and as the palate attenuates, in the finish. The natural lemon candy and chewing stick of licorice sweetness is one of the many things that make this beer outstandingly characterful and multi-dimensional. The hop is another. Gorgeous.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at Bottleworks. Served quite chilled, and the flavors come out better as it warms. The color is that of pure gooseberry, pale sunshine orange. The carbonation is just right--lively with good prickle on the tongue. The most outstanding feature of this well-made beer is the natural bitterness in the finish. That little kick adds depth and complexity. The beer is a palate freshener. Very balanced and clean. Glad to have tried this. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Capitol Cider. Color of cloudy cider, no head. What a fun refreshing beer. I wish I could drink this at 4PM on a hot day. Super balance. The lacto fermentation yields the type of sweetness of chewing on a stick of licorice root. The malts are light, lively and toasty. Salt is not apparent, only making the beer revitalizing. Great job. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob:
It's about time I had a new IPA that made me happy--and a double one no less! Had this on tap at Capitol Cider in Seattle. It came in a teeny tulip. Dark, nearing red. The malts are absolutely scrumptious and well chosen to create a perfect blend and balance. There is no heat and the palate is exceptionally smooth and soft. This is elevated stuff. The aroma starts minty and beckons with bread crust, and that bread crust malt character continues to support this supremely well-structured beer. This is the kind of beer that reminds me why I love beer. Its most outstanding feature is the malt profile. Anyone can throw a pickup truck of hops in a kettle, but few can craft a malt backbone as sturdy and professional as this. You can sink your teeth into it but it never becomes sticky. It has a happy vibe, too.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Stumbling Monk. Snifter. Nicely chilled. Cloudy burnt sienna, stable tight cap. Wisps of cedar smoke mingled with brett and bandaid make for a fun, and for me, inviting aroma. The palate is delightfully clean and tart at the front, and shifts slowly to a firm smoky, ashy finish that lingers just long enough. Lovely carbonation. A mellow malty middle adds body and sweetness for balance. I half expected a fail but the smokey tart profile works for groziskie so why shouldnt it work? Whats most remarkable is that the different beers in the blend seem to stand apart, occupying seperate quarters (or thirds as the case may be) and somehow that is what makes it charming. Its like a beer that multitasks. Really a fun drink.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
beer_name: Birrificio del Ducato Brett Peat Daydream

review_blob:
Big bottle from Total Wine Biscayne Blvd, share with marsonthemoon. Amber orange slightly hazed, with a big rocky head that subsides leaving a lasting cap. Aroma of egg shells, albumen, gooseberries, nectarine. Light palate, lively carbonation, soft but full. Long lingering flavors thanks to generous hopping. Very dry overall, and pleasing on the palate. Balanced blend of brett and bitterness. Gnawing on fruit stones. Then, chewing on citrus pith--navel orange. A little zest to follow. New world character with no one outstanding feature. However, there is a good deal of complexity. This one grew on me.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at MCSVAF. It arrives in a Schlenkerla-shaped glass, with the gradual bulge toward the top. The head is a dollup of ice cream foam, perfectly formed with a caldera. The aroma--the aroma is Beer. Proto-beer. The aroma of our foremothers brewing after a hard days work. It is the proverbial liquid bread beckoning you to drink. The body is light and thick at the same time; dense and luscious. My first thought is that smoked malts are used but remember who we are dealing with here (Andreas Gnstaller) and remembered it is a genuine stein process lending the smoke. The smokiness lingers, and the palate never attenuates, making each sip fresh. Drinkable and sessionable. The follow-through is lighthearted. Simply, amazing. It is an honor to drink a beer of this caliber.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: JUL 31, 2013

Not rating much lately but had to do this. In Kristiansand. Its like a beer archaeology exercise, taking you back in time to Viking era. Draft. Cloudy burnt orange. Aroma has mangosteen, unripe pineapple, buttery diacetyl. Palate is crisp and body big, lively. Toasted fruit skins, pineapple, cooked in campfire, dirty socks. If you appreciate being taken back in time to medieval brewing this is it. Well appreciated.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at Mrs. Parma's in Melbourne. Pours opaque black with slim brown head. Briny purple aroma like the interior is mussel shell. The mouthfeel is spot on for the style and can be taken in gulps or sips as desired. The palate is salty and just right. Dry, drinkable, and good!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught at the Malthouse Wellington. In a series of porters and stouts, this was my favorite. It is a liquid bread character. More specifically, it has a raisin bread crust flavor that is delightful. The palate is just right. Drinkable, sessionable, easy on the tongue, good body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at Delirium in Rio. Nice packaging (corked caged and classy bottle). Blonde and nicely headed. Aroma is yeasty and heavily fruited, but the flavors are dry and sophisticated. The overripe pineapple becomes dried apricot and finishes with a herbal tea dryness that makes this trippel tipple surprisingly moreish. Well done!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at Delirium Cafe in Rio. Pours inky black. Big hoppy nose minty chocolate. Late heat both in aroma and flavor. Nice roast. Not bad.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
